It is to have q subscription psler handed you
every hour in the day, and be called a niggard, il
you refuse your name. 1t is 10 eat turkey and
drink wine at dearer rate than your neishbors
1t is to have every college, nfrmary, and asylum.
make run upon the bank Of your benevolence, and
then wonder at the smallness Of the dividend 1t
is to have sectarians contend for the keeping Of
your conscience, and lawyers struggle for the keep
ing of purse. 1t is to be embered from Sc
guin to Talbot Island, whenever dinner or a loan
Is wanted. L. is to be taxed for more than you are
WORTH and never to be believed when you say So
Il i. to have addition ofdoars, subtraction of com


forts, and multiplication Of anzietles end in divs


ION among spendthrft heirs. II Is 70 have the in
terest of every one about YOU exceed tier princi


pie It is to make up to the merchant all the prof
its he loses by knavery, or frugaity. 1t is never
70 be allowed to be upon easy terms, even with a
coat or shoe. 1t is to be married for your money.
or have wife always casting up the sum total OF
the dollars size brought. II is to have your sons
steps surrounded By " nanttaps,' and your daugh-
ter made target for the speculating and selfish 70
aim at. It is to measure friendship BY the length
Of your purse, to buy hattery, ard sell happiness


!. is to have debtors smile upon you, and knaves
shake you BY the hand. i is to have dyspeptic
wife aud pale children, 1t is TO have sons 90 to
college to buy themes Of wiser heads, and dauSh-
ters' brains turned By the flattery af fools 1t i
20 be invited to drink poor wine that you may give
better in return. It is to have your lady's peace
disturbed BY higher feather, brighter dia-
mond. It is to buy green peas at nine shillings.
and relish them not, because your neiaibor gives
two dollars, II is to have relations wish YOU a
short life and 3 long will Itistot have your widow
mourn bitterly provided her fortune depends on
perpetual widawhood. !; j. to have more tempta.
lions in this world than other men; and lastly, &c
find the entrance to better more difficult than tc
the rest Of mankind Mass. journal.

MIR. Granger rose and said he held in his hand,
several petitions signed by Sitizens Of the highsu
responsibility, relating to subject, which, for ssr
eral months, had produced much exciiemsn, 10 ii.
western part Of this slate.


II was known 10 most Of the members oflhe Hou,
that person named VIM Morgan, who was SUD-
posed to have written. and TO be then sbou, publish
ing, book disclosing the secrets Of The institution
of freemasonry, was, in The month Of Seplemb.,
last, taken from the village Of Batavia, under color
Of legal process, and lodged in the jail Of The silae
Of Canandsigua. from which confinement he was
subsequently, liberated, and forciby taken 10 the Nj
agara frontier--slnce which time said Morgan had
not been seem nor his faie been certainly ascertain.
ed. This statement lie was authorised in making
from the TACT that several persons engaged in Ibis
outrage had been arrested, had plead guilty to The
indictments found sgainst them, and arc now suhsr
ing In the jail Of the county OF Onafo, the penal.
ties OF the law.


Since the period OF these convictions, belief gain
ed consideration that Morgan must have been pvt
to death. Agita.ed and alarmed BY transaction 50
extraordinary the cilizens Of many Of the western
villages and counties, have assembled in public
meetings, and have appointed communists Tor The
investigation Of this transaction.


Those members oil these committees who pro-
ceeded to the frontier have become satisfied that
'ne hIe OF morgan nad oeen taken, out lhey repre-
sent that so extensive is this combination, that The
ordinary process Of cur courts is not competent to
reach The many branches Of thi, conspiracy and By
the papers | now present, they ask this house 10
strengthen the arm Of justice in such manner a. 10
reach this case.


Mr. G. said he was not prepared to expre. IN
his place any opinion upon The facts assumed 10 The
memorial, SO fer as they related TO The murder Of
this unfortunate man. The evidences upon which
these averments arc made have not yet been trans
mlted: he however felt called on to say. that there
is much reason to believe that this conspiracy Tor
the seizure and disposition OF Morgan, though nei
embracing as many persons. was as wide spread as
had been the honest indignation and excitement
produced by this unparalleled outrage upon the LID
eres, if mol upon the life o one of our citizens.


MIR. G. called for the reading of the petitions
which were read and referred 10 the commislse %
courts Of justice.

r. my Daughter on her Birthday


DF BERNARD BARToc.
Ny child this is thy natal day,


And might fathers prayer
For thee inspire his votve lay,
What blessing shouldst thou shares
Shall wit, CT wealth or beauty, move
Thy sire 20 bend his knee,-
hold thee far too dear my love,
To ask these things for thee.
If sish Of mine might prove Of worth,
Be this thy portion given
Thy Mothers blarneless life on ear,h.-
Thy Mothers lott Heaven!

ExEcuT,yE DEPARTMENT, GEoReIA,2


.uilledrerille 21st Feb. 1897.


GENTLEMEN: was glad to learn by the mail
of today. that measures had been taken by the
President, subsequently to the communication OF
the Secretary of War, of the 29th ut., 70 procure
the lands left out by the instrument called the
New Treaty. have uniformly urged TINS mea
sure on the General Government, from the moment
Il professed willingness, contlngently, to adopt
it. and in no part of the correspondence more
strenuously than in my letter to the Secretary OF
War, of the Goth January, copy OF which was
transmitted to you by the last mail. 1t was known
to me, that sincere desire to procure them, ac-
companied BY corresponding efforts, could not fail
of success, and had felt both surprise and regret
that any reluctance had been manifested to have
recourse to the necessary measure without ueiay.
The reasons assigned for the postponement were,
in no aspect of them, satsfactory and so the Pre-
sident was informed in candid and amicable spi-
rit. You are at liberty to state to the councils
before whom you represent the interests and rights
Of this State, what has been repeatedly represent
ed to the President himself, that the Governor OF
Georgia has never, at any time, entertained the
idea of resorting to military force to counteract
measures of the Government of the United States,
but on the occasion where it was deemed better
in honor, in conscience, and in duty, to sacrifice
every thing we hold dear, than unresistngly tol
submit. On the last occasion, when military co.
ercion was threatened, the President was promptly
and candidly informed of my resolution to meet
that coercion in military manner. So far as
determination expressed to resort to the civil
process, it was decided to resort to the like pro-
cess 10 sustain, according to the Constitution and
laws of the United States and the Constitution
and laws Of the State, the public officers OF Geor-
gia engaged in the execution Of their duties under
the orders directly Of its Legislative and Execu-
tive authorities-an obligation, on part enjoin
ed By the very sanction which the President, in
his late message, refers to- as being paramount to
any human power, and of course, equally impera-
tive with US as with him. cannot acknowledge
a power in the United States TO bring before its
Judicial Tribunals for trial, and judgment, and
punishment, the Governor, or Judges, or Repre-.
sentatiyes, or other Ohicers such, acting under
the authority of the Constitution and laws of the
States. Whilst, therefore. no intention exists to
resist the Civil Authority Of the United States con-
slider myself bound to afford to Officers of Georgia
acting under my orders, all the protection can,
consistently with the Constitution aud laws and
can never admit that wrongs done by Officers oI
the United States to Officers Of the State, shall
not be inquired into and redresscd by the State
Tribunals.


| consider all questions of mere sovereignty as
matter for negotiation between the States and
United States. until the competent Tribunal shall
be assigned by the Constitution itself for the ad-
justment Of them.


l. am not wanting in confidence in the Supreme
Court Of the United States in all cases falling
within their acknowledged jurisdiction. AS men,
would not hesitate to refer our cause to their ar.
btration or umpirage. On an amcable issue made
up between the United States and ourselves, we
might have had difficulty in referring it to them
as Judges, protesting, at the time, against the
jurisdiction. and saving rights of sovereignty
II the United States will with without the con-
sent Of Georgia, make question before the Su-
preme Court. it will be for the Government of
Georgia ultimately to submit, or not to the deci-
sion of that Tribunal But, according to my lin
tied conception, the Supreme Court is not made.
bv The Constitution Of the United States, the ar.
siter in controversies involving rights of sovereign.
ty between the States and the United States The
Senate of the United States may have so consid.
cred IT. because it has been proposed to make that
honorable body itself the arbiter and umpire be-
tween them The States cannot consent to refer
to the Supreme Court as of right and obligation,
questions OF sovereignty between them and the
United States. because that Court, being Of exclu-
sve appointment by the Government Of the Uni
ted States, will make the United States the Judge
IN their own cause this reason is equally appca-
ble to State Tribunal. Hence, the difficulties
lkely oarise even by resort to the civil process,
and thus you wiperceive how infinitely preferable
it is to carry into effect Immediately the measure
contemplated by the Instructions to the Agent.


1t is indeed to be lamented, that person so well
known here for his unftness should have been char
ged with such an office. but this very knowledge
will make the failure, if the failure happen, not our
fault, but the fault of his employers.


Ot all the wrongs wantonly and cruelty inflicted
none have been borne with more patience than the
charge Of seeking dissolution of the Union. Nv
intentions have been to cement and perpetuate il.
BY preserving, inyiolate the rights Of the parties
to the compact, without which, the compact would
be Of no value, and to this end have Increasingly


abored Time may probably disclose, that a very

To the Delegation Of the State Of Georgia, ~ the

From the ". r. Commercial Advertiser, March H.


FROM ALnAsr.-The proceedings Of both Hou
ses Of the Legislature both inter e.iing and i'm
portant on Saturday. In the Senate, the commii'ss
on engrossed bills. reported that the bill making
donation TO the Greeks, was not tlco thirds bill
but could be passed BY bare majority. This opin-
ion was sanctioned BY q vote OF 10 to 9. The quss
tion then recurred on the final passage Of the bill
and it was carried in the affirmative, 16 to l3. ln
the Assembly Mr.. Buckn, chairman Of the COM
mitee on courts Of JUSTICE stated that he had been
instructed by that committee to move that they b
discharged from the further consideration Of the
memorial presented TO the legislature on The subject
OF the abduction o: William Morgan. He obserr
ed that various considerations had Induced the com
niiee to give such instructions; amongst Others
that majority Of that committee belonged 10 the
fraternity OF ireemasons and he therefore NOV
ed that the subject be referred 60 a select COM
m'lee. Mr.. T. II. Smith inquired why lree.ma-
sons should be excluded from serving as commit
tee on such subject. Were they dishonest or dis
honorable men? Mr.. Bucklin did not reply. The
motion prevailed, and committee of Ave was ap.
pointed, 10 which the memorial was referred. The
committes consist Of Messrs. Granger, Brasber, Sill,
Barsow, and Cowles

Written for the Greek Concert at -fev-haren
Rouse We, at a nations cali
Rouse and rescue, one and all
Help. or Liberty shall fall


Fall in blood and shame,
Shame to him, who coldly draws
backward from the noblest cause
Not to him who fights and fa's-


His glorious name.
Sons Of more than mortal sres-.
They have Ii, again their fires.
Or to be their funeral pyres


Or their sun Of fame.
Hear We not the widows cry
nHelp us, or we faint and die
See, the murderous foe is nigh


Hark the wasting fame.
whittier can we fly for aid
Where is now the warriors bladcs
Low the mighty heart is laid,


Death alone could tame.
To the mountain-to the cave,
Let US fy, and weep the brave
Better die than live slave


Better death than shame
o forbid it chosen land
Open wide the helping hand
Pour thy corn and vine like sand


What is wealth to fame
Quick! before the fame expire
Feed--O! feed the holy fire:
Feed-and it shall kindle higher


Win generous name.

full articles.headline: MISERIEs OF WEALTH.
full articles.article:
Suggested 6y reading HnzIfs +" ,Fsers. IF Poverty"


It is to have q subscription psler handed you
every hour in the day, and be called a niggard, il
you refuse your name. 1t is 10 eat turkey and
drink wine at dearer rate than your neishbors
1t is to have every college, nfrmary, and asylum.
make run upon the bank Of your benevolence, and
then wonder at the smallness Of the dividend 1t
is to have sectarians contend for the keeping Of
your conscience, and lawyers struggle for the keep
ing of purse. 1t is to be embered from Sc
guin to Talbot Island, whenever dinner or a loan
Is wanted. L. is to be taxed for more than you are
WORTH and never to be believed when you say So
Il i. to have addition ofdoars, subtraction of com


forts, and multiplication Of anzietles end in divs


ION among spendthrft heirs. II Is 70 have the in
terest of every one about YOU exceed tier princi


pie It is to make up to the merchant all the prof
its he loses by knavery, or frugaity. 1t is never
70 be allowed to be upon easy terms, even with a
coat or shoe. 1t is to be married for your money.
or have wife always casting up the sum total OF
the dollars size brought. II is to have your sons
steps surrounded By " nanttaps,' and your daugh-
ter made target for the speculating and selfish 70
aim at. It is to measure friendship BY the length
Of your purse, to buy hattery, ard sell happiness


!. is to have debtors smile upon you, and knaves
shake you BY the hand. i is to have dyspeptic
wife aud pale children, 1t is TO have sons 90 to
college to buy themes Of wiser heads, and dauSh-
ters' brains turned By the flattery af fools 1t i
20 be invited to drink poor wine that you may give
better in return. It is to have your lady's peace
disturbed BY higher feather, brighter dia-
mond. It is to buy green peas at nine shillings.
and relish them not, because your neiaibor gives
two dollars, II is to have relations wish YOU a
short life and 3 long will Itistot have your widow
mourn bitterly provided her fortune depends on
perpetual widawhood. !; j. to have more tempta.
lions in this world than other men; and lastly, &c
find the entrance to better more difficult than tc
the rest Of mankind Mass. journal.

the President and Heads Of Departments. s;,ss

Clinton College--A bill was before the house Il
representatives on Friday last, to incorporate col.
lege with this name in Fayette county. Mr.. Ri.
ner advocated the bill, but objected to the nams
lie did not mish TO confer an honor Of that kind
upon man, uho during the arar opposed tn, gor. m
ernment, aud endeavored to bring disgrace upon he
country. When the bill came up on second
reading, on Friday, on motion Of MIR. Irwin, Gin.
ton was stricken out and Madison inserted BY
unanimous vote. Intel

full articles.headline: NEW YORK ASSEMBLY, March 9.
full articles.article:
MIR. Granger rose and said he held in his hand,
several petitions signed by Sitizens Of the highsu
responsibility, relating to subject, which, for ssr
eral months, had produced much exciiemsn, 10 ii.
western part Of this slate.


II was known 10 most Of the members oflhe Hou,
that person named VIM Morgan, who was SUD-
posed to have written. and TO be then sbou, publish
ing, book disclosing the secrets Of The institution
of freemasonry, was, in The month Of Seplemb.,
last, taken from the village Of Batavia, under color
Of legal process, and lodged in the jail Of The silae
Of Canandsigua. from which confinement he was
subsequently, liberated, and forciby taken 10 the Nj
agara frontier--slnce which time said Morgan had
not been seem nor his faie been certainly ascertain.
ed. This statement lie was authorised in making
from the TACT that several persons engaged in Ibis
outrage had been arrested, had plead guilty to The
indictments found sgainst them, and arc now suhsr
ing In the jail Of the county OF Onafo, the penal.
ties OF the law.


Since the period OF these convictions, belief gain
ed consideration that Morgan must have been pvt
to death. Agita.ed and alarmed BY transaction 50
extraordinary the cilizens Of many Of the western
villages and counties, have assembled in public
meetings, and have appointed communists Tor The
investigation Of this transaction.


Those members oil these committees who pro-
ceeded to the frontier have become satisfied that
'ne hIe OF morgan nad oeen taken, out lhey repre-
sent that so extensive is this combination, that The
ordinary process Of cur courts is not competent to
reach The many branches Of thi, conspiracy and By
the papers | now present, they ask this house 10
strengthen the arm Of justice in such manner a. 10
reach this case.


Mr. G. said he was not prepared to expre. IN
his place any opinion upon The facts assumed 10 The
memorial, SO fer as they related TO The murder Of
this unfortunate man. The evidences upon which
these averments arc made have not yet been trans
mlted: he however felt called on to say. that there
is much reason to believe that this conspiracy Tor
the seizure and disposition OF Morgan, though nei
embracing as many persons. was as wide spread as
had been the honest indignation and excitement
produced by this unparalleled outrage upon the LID
eres, if mol upon the life o one of our citizens.


MIR. G. called for the reading of the petitions
which were read and referred 10 the commislse %
courts Of justice.

full articles.headline: r. my Daughter on her Birthday.
full articles.article:
r. my Daughter on her Birthday


DF BERNARD BARToc.
Ny child this is thy natal day,


And might fathers prayer
For thee inspire his votve lay,
What blessing shouldst thou shares
Shall wit, CT wealth or beauty, move
Thy sire 20 bend his knee,-
hold thee far too dear my love,
To ask these things for thee.
If sish Of mine might prove Of worth,
Be this thy portion given
Thy Mothers blarneless life on ear,h.-
Thy Mothers lott Heaven!

full articles.headline:
LETTER FROM GOV. TROUP.
To the Delegation Of the State Of Georgia, ~ the


Congress of the United States.
full articles.article:
ExEcuT,yE DEPARTMENT, GEoReIA,2


.uilledrerille 21st Feb. 1897.


GENTLEMEN: was glad to learn by the mail
of today. that measures had been taken by the
President, subsequently to the communication OF
the Secretary of War, of the 29th ut., 70 procure
the lands left out by the instrument called the
New Treaty. have uniformly urged TINS mea
sure on the General Government, from the moment
Il professed willingness, contlngently, to adopt
it. and in no part of the correspondence more
strenuously than in my letter to the Secretary OF
War, of the Goth January, copy OF which was
transmitted to you by the last mail. 1t was known
to me, that sincere desire to procure them, ac-
companied BY corresponding efforts, could not fail
of success, and had felt both surprise and regret
that any reluctance had been manifested to have
recourse to the necessary measure without ueiay.
The reasons assigned for the postponement were,
in no aspect of them, satsfactory and so the Pre-
sident was informed in candid and amicable spi-
rit. You are at liberty to state to the councils
before whom you represent the interests and rights
Of this State, what has been repeatedly represent
ed to the President himself, that the Governor OF
Georgia has never, at any time, entertained the
idea of resorting to military force to counteract
measures of the Government of the United States,
but on the occasion where it was deemed better
in honor, in conscience, and in duty, to sacrifice
every thing we hold dear, than unresistngly tol
submit. On the last occasion, when military co.
ercion was threatened, the President was promptly
and candidly informed of my resolution to meet
that coercion in military manner. So far as
determination expressed to resort to the civil
process, it was decided to resort to the like pro-
cess 10 sustain, according to the Constitution and
laws of the United States and the Constitution
and laws Of the State, the public officers OF Geor-
gia engaged in the execution Of their duties under
the orders directly Of its Legislative and Execu-
tive authorities-an obligation, on part enjoin
ed By the very sanction which the President, in
his late message, refers to- as being paramount to
any human power, and of course, equally impera-
tive with US as with him. cannot acknowledge
a power in the United States TO bring before its
Judicial Tribunals for trial, and judgment, and
punishment, the Governor, or Judges, or Repre-.
sentatiyes, or other Ohicers such, acting under
the authority of the Constitution and laws of the
States. Whilst, therefore. no intention exists to
resist the Civil Authority Of the United States con-
slider myself bound to afford to Officers of Georgia
acting under my orders, all the protection can,
consistently with the Constitution aud laws and
can never admit that wrongs done by Officers oI
the United States to Officers Of the State, shall
not be inquired into and redresscd by the State
Tribunals.


| consider all questions of mere sovereignty as
matter for negotiation between the States and
United States. until the competent Tribunal shall
be assigned by the Constitution itself for the ad-
justment Of them.


l. am not wanting in confidence in the Supreme
Court Of the United States in all cases falling
within their acknowledged jurisdiction. AS men,
would not hesitate to refer our cause to their ar.
btration or umpirage. On an amcable issue made
up between the United States and ourselves, we
might have had difficulty in referring it to them
as Judges, protesting, at the time, against the
jurisdiction. and saving rights of sovereignty
II the United States will with without the con-
sent Of Georgia, make question before the Su-
preme Court. it will be for the Government of
Georgia ultimately to submit, or not to the deci-
sion of that Tribunal But, according to my lin
tied conception, the Supreme Court is not made.
bv The Constitution Of the United States, the ar.
siter in controversies involving rights of sovereign.
ty between the States and the United States The
Senate of the United States may have so consid.
cred IT. because it has been proposed to make that
honorable body itself the arbiter and umpire be-
tween them The States cannot consent to refer
to the Supreme Court as of right and obligation,
questions OF sovereignty between them and the
United States. because that Court, being Of exclu-
sve appointment by the Government Of the Uni
ted States, will make the United States the Judge
IN their own cause this reason is equally appca-
ble to State Tribunal. Hence, the difficulties
lkely oarise even by resort to the civil process,
and thus you wiperceive how infinitely preferable
it is to carry into effect Immediately the measure
contemplated by the Instructions to the Agent.


1t is indeed to be lamented, that person so well
known here for his unftness should have been char
ged with such an office. but this very knowledge
will make the failure, if the failure happen, not our
fault, but the fault of his employers.


Ot all the wrongs wantonly and cruelty inflicted
none have been borne with more patience than the
charge Of seeking dissolution of the Union. Nv
intentions have been to cement and perpetuate il.
BY preserving, inyiolate the rights Of the parties
to the compact, without which, the compact would
be Of no value, and to this end have Increasingly


abored Time may probably disclose, that a very

From the ". r. Commercial Advertiser, March H.


FROM ALnAsr.-The proceedings Of both Hou
ses Of the Legislature both inter e.iing and i'm
portant on Saturday. In the Senate, the commii'ss
on engrossed bills. reported that the bill making
donation TO the Greeks, was not tlco thirds bill
but could be passed BY bare majority. This opin-
ion was sanctioned BY q vote OF 10 to 9. The quss
tion then recurred on the final passage Of the bill
and it was carried in the affirmative, 16 to l3. ln
the Assembly Mr.. Buckn, chairman Of the COM
mitee on courts Of JUSTICE stated that he had been
instructed by that committee to move that they b
discharged from the further consideration Of the
memorial presented TO the legislature on The subject
OF the abduction o: William Morgan. He obserr
ed that various considerations had Induced the com
niiee to give such instructions; amongst Others
that majority Of that committee belonged 10 the
fraternity OF ireemasons and he therefore NOV
ed that the subject be referred 60 a select COM
m'lee. Mr.. T. II. Smith inquired why lree.ma-
sons should be excluded from serving as commit
tee on such subject. Were they dishonest or dis
honorable men? Mr.. Bucklin did not reply. The
motion prevailed, and committee of Ave was ap.
pointed, 10 which the memorial was referred. The
committes consist Of Messrs. Granger, Brasber, Sill,
Barsow, and Cowles

full articles.headline: soso BIZ psRcIvAL.
full articles.article:
Written for the Greek Concert at -fev-haren
Rouse We, at a nations cali
Rouse and rescue, one and all
Help. or Liberty shall fall


Fall in blood and shame,
Shame to him, who coldly draws
backward from the noblest cause
Not to him who fights and fa's-


His glorious name.
Sons Of more than mortal sres-.
They have Ii, again their fires.
Or to be their funeral pyres


Or their sun Of fame.
Hear We not the widows cry
nHelp us, or we faint and die
See, the murderous foe is nigh


Hark the wasting fame.
whittier can we fly for aid
Where is now the warriors bladcs
Low the mighty heart is laid,


Death alone could tame.
To the mountain-to the cave,
Let US fy, and weep the brave
Better die than live slave


Better death than shame
o forbid it chosen land
Open wide the helping hand
Pour thy corn and vine like sand


What is wealth to fame
Quick! before the fame expire
Feed--O! feed the holy fire:
Feed-and it shall kindle higher


Win generous name.
